text:
Situation A. Revisiting Some Number Patterns

After trying the locker activity, students in Ms. Keusch's class made several conjectures about number patterns they observed. For each conjecture, decide whether it is true, false, or sometimes true. Provide reasons for your answer.

Conjecture 1

A locker number touched by two students is a common multiple of the student numbers.

Conjecture 2

Given two locker numbers, the number of the student who touches both lockers is a common factor of the locker numbers.
True. Since the factors are touching the lockers, both factors would have that locker number as a common multiple.
True. The factors of the locker number open and close the lockers. So if two lockers are touched by the same two people, the factors must be in common.

Conjecture 3

The locker number touched by exactly two students are prime numbers.

Conjecture 4

Locker numbers of the form 2N are one more than a prime number.
True. Locker numbers that are touched by exactly two students are numbers with only two factors: prime numbers.
False except if N is also a prime.

Conjecture 5

The locker numbers that are prime will remain open after all students are done opening ad closing them.

Conjecture 6

The prime factorization of the open lockers has a number that can be expressed as a power of 2 or N2.

False.

Prime numbers have exactly two factors. So the locker will open with Student 1 and close with the student whose number is equal to the prime.

This is only true in some cases:

4 = 22 (true in this case)

9 = 32 (true in this case)

16 = 24

25 = 52 (true in this case)

36 = 22 â‹… 32 (Students might argue that this is partially true in this case.)

Note: Students might think of these as "double paper clip number" from the game in Problem 1.2.
